title: Jacawitz
text:
Jacawitz () (also spelt Jakawitz, Jakawits, Qʼaqʼawits and Hacavitz) was a mountain <a href="List%20of%20Maya%20gods%20and%20supernatural%20beings">god</a> of the <a href="Mesoamerican%20chronology">Postclassic</a> <a href="K%CA%BCiche%CA%BC%20people">Kʼicheʼ</a> <a href="Maya%20civilization">Maya</a> of highland <a href="Guatemala">Guatemala</a>. He was the patron of the Ajaw Kʼicheʼ lineage and was a companion of the sun god <a href="Tohil">Tohil</a>. It is likely that he received <a href="Human%20sacrifice%20in%20Maya%20culture">human sacrifice</a>. The word "jacawitz" means "mountain" in the lowland <a href="Maya%20languages">Maya language</a>, and the word "qʼaqʼawitz" of the highland Maya means "fire mountain", which suggests that Jacawitz was mainly a fire deity, much like Tohil. In the <a href="Mam%20language">Mam language</a>, the similar word "xqʼaqwitz" means "yellow wasp" and the wasp was an important symbol of the deity and its associated lineage. In the <a href="Ch%CA%BCol%20language">Cholan languages</a>, "jacawitz" means "first mountain", linking the god with the first mountain of creation.
In the Kʼicheʼ epic <a href="Popul%20Vuh">Popul Vuh</a>, the first people gathered at the mythical place <a href="Tollan">Tollan</a> to receive their gods, and Mahucutah, one of the gathered Kʼicheʼ lords, received Jacawitz. The mid-9th century Stela 8 at the <a href="Mesoamerican%20chronology">Terminal Classic</a> lowland Maya site of <a href="Seibal">Seibal</a> describes a visitor to the city named Hakawitzil. This is an early spelling of Jacawitz and <a href="Mayanist">Mayanist</a>s <a href="Linda%20Schele">Linda Schele</a> and Peter Mathews have proposed that the event depicted on this stela gave rise to the <a href="Founding%20myth">foundation legends</a> of the Kʼicheʼ. As well as being mentioned frequently in the Popul Vuh, Jacawitz is also mentioned in the Kʼicheʼ document "Título de los Señores de Totonicapán".
Jacawitz was one of a triad of Kʼicheʼ deities, the other two being Tohil and the goddess <a href="Awilix">Awilix</a>, all three were sometimes collectively referred to as Tohil, the principal member of the triad. The concept of a trinity of deities was an ancient one in Maya culture, dating back to the <a href="Mesoamerican%20chronology">Preclassic period</a>.
Temple of Jacawitz.
The Ahaw Kʼicheʼ were the founding lineage of the Kʼicheʼ Maya, although they later lost power to the Kaweq lineage; as they lost status within the kingdom, so did their patron god. The temple of Jacawitz at the Kʼicheʼ capital of <a href="Q%CA%BCumarkaj">Qʼumarkaj</a> was one of the three tallest buildings in the city, although it faced away from the main plaza. The temple is a large mound south of the plaza, its stonework has been stripped away making its original form uncertain, although a 19th-century plan of the city recorded it as a <a href="Mesoamerican%20pyramids">pyramid</a>. This pyramid temple was part of a complex that consisted of a patio enclosed by the temple on the northern side, a palace on the south side and a long building on the east. The Jakawitz temple complex has not yet been investigated archaeologically. The 19th century drawings by Miguel Rivera y Maestre suggest that the temple was a narrow building with four or five terraces.
